trial_identification.studytitle: Study on Adults and Iodine Deficiency (SAID)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled intervention trial of the effect of iodine supplementation on thyroglobulin concentration in mildly iodine deficient young adults
trial_identification.trialacronym: Study on Adults and Iodine Deficiency (SAID)

interventions.interventions: Oral iodine supplement (150 mcg Iodine/day) for 6 months. Tablets will be supplied in a 28 day blister pack/month; blister packs will be returned and remaining tablets measured to monitor adherance.
interventions.comparator: Placebo supplement (0 mcg Iodine/day) for 6 months

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in serum thyroglobulin concentration measured by assay.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy, free of thyroid disease, eats 2 or less servings of commercial bread/day, not taking iodine supplements, not pregnant or planning a pregnancy, not breastfeeding, with urinary iodine concentration less than 100 mcg/L.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Urinary Iodine Concentration >100 mcg/L Presence of thyroid antibodies Low T4 or High TSH

trial_design.concealment: Recruitment by advertisement. Randomisation will be planned and generated by a researched not directly involved in participant recruitment or data collection. Allocation will be concealed by sealed opaque numbered envelopes.
trial_design.sequence: RAND on Excel in blocks stratified for sex
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Sample size was determined using STATA based on difference of 4 mcg/L at the end of the intervention between supplemented and placebo groups. Regression Analysis, Mixed Models

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Otago Medical Research Foundation Dept Physiology University of Otago PO Box 913 Dunedin 9054

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this study is to determine the efficacy of thyroglobulin concentration in assessing iodine status in individuals.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Academic Services University of Otago PO Box 56 Dunedin 9054
